text: I worked almost 40 years in a commercial company.  It the beginning, it was over 1500 employees. Towards the end it shrank to less than 150.  Due to politics in the company, I was miserable going to work every day.  Real estate market was high, mortgage paid, and I always had a desire to retire out of the country.  While on a 6 week vacation in the Philippines, we found a great house and put a deposit,  once you retire, your SS benefits will never increase because you are no longer contributing to SS.  Therefore, in this case, collect immediately.  My SS is deposited in my US bank and set up before retiring, i can transfer dollars to a dollar account in the Philippines.

text: How much you pay the IRS depends on your TOTAL income.  The more income you have, the higher your tax rate.  Therefore, if you start collecting SS while you are still working, your total income will be higher.  What's the result?  Higher taxes.
author: Vlogger Grandpa, USA

text: Just remember that the projected SS benefit at FRA, on the statements from that you get from SSA, assumes that your latest annual income will continue until you reach FRA.  SSA assumes that it will get the same amount of FICA tax from both employee and employer. If you start working less hours to stay below the SSA earnings limit, this will result in a lower amount of FICA tax. Consequently, this will reduce the benefit that you will receive at FRA, since the benefit is based on the last 35 years of FICA taxes paid.  Also remember that the spousal benefit is usually 50% of the primary beneficiary‚Äôs pension if the claim is made at FRA.  If the spousal benefit is claimed earlier than FRA, the percentage is reduced by a formula from the SSA and could be as low as 32%, instead of the 50%.

text: Thanks for breaking it down, and I have been thinking of receiving my SS at the earliest possible.  I'm Blessed to have retired at age 41 years young as U.S. military officer with over 21-years of service.  While in service, I used my housing allowance to buy real estate and also started investing in stock with then Datek  in late 1990s which is now TD Ameritrade.  While working I also established College 529 for my 3-children and also established Custodial Accounts with then Scottrade for my 3-children as soon as they're issued their SSN.  When I retired from U.S. Army, I had 4-properties in 2-low cost states.  One thing I learned being raised by single-mother along with 4-siblings, is to live frugal life style.  I normally bought used cars EXCEPT when I retired, I bought a brand new car - cash.  Now at age 49, I started selling properties to simplify my lifestyle.  I used to be workaholic, and now travels/cruise to enjoy fruits of my labour since I started working at 15-years young.  I'm Blessed to have no debt other than the mortgage.  My thought process is the same, take SS at 62 since we're NOT guaranteed tomorrow.  Again, maraming salamat po for sharing.

text: The earliest a widow or widower can start receiving Social Security survivors benefits based on age will remain at age 60. Widows or widowers benefits based on age can start any time between age 60 and full retirement age as a survivor. If the benefits start at an earlier age, they are reduced a fraction of a percent for each month before full retirement age.  If a person receives widow's or widower's benefits, and will qualify for a retirement benefit that's more than their survivors benefit, they can switch to their own retirement benefit as early as age 62 or as late as age 70. The rules are complicated and vary depending on the situation. Talk to a Social Security representative about the options available.

text: A minimum requirement to collect Social Security retirement benefits is performing enough work. The Social Security Administration defines "enough work" as earning 40 Social Security credits. More specifically, in 2020, an individual receives one credit for each $1,410 in income, and they can earn a maximum of four credits per year. So, 40 credits are roughly equal to 10 years of work.

text: I like the video; it's well done. However, determining when to begin receiving SSI isn't quite so simple.  While the numbers in themselves make sense, there are complications to be borne in mind.  The median average life expectancy of 62 year old men is about 25 years and 28 years for women.  What this means is that (using the 3% historic annual inflation discount), unless you have a significant illness or a family history of much shorter than average life spans, the smart move is to wait as long as you can.  Why? because every year you live beyond the break even point of 81 or 82, you will have made more money, altogether, by delaying your SSI claim.  Of course, if you have no other source of income, you'll have to begin collecting earlier than you'd like just to survive.  Another point to consider is that in most years your social security payments will be increased by a % that offsets inflation.  So, the longer you wait to collect SSI, the greater number of dollars each percentage point represents.  The analysis stops at full retirement age.  In my case, 66 years.  for each year you wait, beyond full retirement age, to begin your payments, you get an additional 8% until age 70.  So, for me (using his $$) this would be $1,320 per month at 70 rather than $1,000 at full retirement age, or $733 at 62.  If you're reasonably healthy and you have other income, it really is smart to wait til 70.  Finally, the penalty for working and collecting SSI ($2 for $1 I believe) ends at full retirement age (66).  There is no such penalty for W2 income earned after that age.   Just my $.02.

text: The earliest that you can file is when you are 61 years and 9 months old. https://www.ssa.gov/planners/retire/applying3.html Since you will turn 62 in Jan 2020, you can start the filing process in Nov 2019. There are some weird SSA rules on when you will receive your first payment.  SSA only pays after a whole month.  Unless you were born on Jan 1, your first whole month would be Feb 2020 and you will receive your first payment in March 2020.  Despite the SSA pronouncement that you can start receiving benefits when you turn 62, you actually only start to receive the money when you are 62 years and 2 months old.

text: Some kababayans may not be aware that they might also be entitled to social security benefit from the PHL SSS.  If you worked and contributed for at least 10 years (120 monthly contributions) before immigrating abroad, you can claim your benefit at age 60.  You do not have to be a dual citizen to file the claim.  If you are 60+ and have not yet filed a claim, you will receive an initial lump sum equivalent to 13 months benefit per year that you missed, plus accumulated interest.  If you have less than 120 contributions (for example, you only worked for 8 years in PHL before immigrating abroad) and you are less than 65 years old, you can still pay additional contributions to make up and be eligible.  More information can be found here:  https://www.sss.gov.ph/sss/appmanager/pages.jsp?page=retirementqualifying

text: The two-month delay in receiving your first SS payment is another example of weird SSA rules.  Social Security does not make partial-month payments. Unless you were born on May 1st, your first full month of eligibility is June.  Since the Social Security Administration pays individuals a month behind, the person will receive the June benefit in July. The check will arrive on the 2nd, 3rd, or 4th Wednesday, depending on your day of birth.  For example, if you were born on May 10th you will get your first payment on July 10 but if you were born one day later, May 11, you have to wait until July 17.  The shortest waiting time is for a person born on May 1 (42 days) but, the worst-case scenario is the person born the following day on May 2, who has to wait 69 days before receiving his first SS payment.  So the person born on May 1 will receive his first payment almost one whole month earlier than the person born on May 2!  So, while at first glance you might think you can get your benefits when you turn 62, the first payment does not happen until you are 62 years and 2  months old...

text: ¬†@Vlogger Grandpa, USA¬† Even if you earned exactly $17,640 to avoid the $1/$2 penalty, you are still giving back some of the money in terms of FICA tax.  At the current FICA rate of 7.65%, you are giving back $1350 out of the $17,640 to the SSA.  If you are free-lancing or self-employed during retirement, the rate is 15.3% or $2700 back to the SSA even if you earned exactly $17,640.
author: mvescuadra

text: Tax is something that is completely separate.  The problem is that the benefit you should be getting may be reduced or completely eliminated depending on your income from work.  As far as tax goes, SS benefit is always taxable unless your "total income including SS benefit" do not exceed your total standard deduction.

text: ¬†@Vlogger Grandpa, USA¬† There is a small gotcha in this situation.  SSA‚Äôs calculation of your benefit is made on the assumption that you will continue to earn at least the same amount as your last reported annual salary and consequently the same FICA deductions.  If you stop working at age 55, use your ‚Äòother source‚Äô and collect at 62, you will have 7 years of zero salary and zero FICA deductions in the SSA records.  This will result in a smaller benefit than what is currently projected in your SSA records.

author: Magikerong Sugarol

text: Like  he said, it depends on where you will retire and the lifestyle you have. If you decide to live in Manila, I think you're main concern will be housing. The price for the condo unit back in 2012 has tremendously increased. But between $400-700 monthly rent will be a very nice house/apartment . Less if you choose a smaller one and of course it also depends where in Manila. Other places are far more expensive than others. I think food wise, you 'll be okay with $200/month if you plan on cooking at home. Eating out will be different of course. Not sure if you can use your benefit for housing loan in the Philippines if you decide to acquire a property. People who served has a very good discount or rate for housing loans. Not sure if you are aware of it. We have a VA ofc that you can go to in Pasay, which is in Manila ( I'm not mistaken, it is near the US embassy) and they have providers that can see you. With the New Mission Act, you can be referred to a non-VA provider if they can not address your health concern. If you have not established yourself as a pt within VA, now is the time to get to it so that you'll be in the system and hopefully, it will be much easier for you to transition there. And so, if you decide to live in the province and you'll encounter any health issues, you can see a provider locally and doesn't have to travel Manila to go to the VA ofc and they can simply make the consult/referral for you. At least, this is how I understand it. Better to ask the VA still. Hope that helps.

author: Jimmy Arce

text: It really depends on where exactly you're going to go, and the kind of lifestyle you're going to have.  I suggest that you do what I did.  That is, when you go on vacation spend more time looking at rentals so you know how much they are in the area you are interested in, estimate your food expenses, and other expenses you can inquire about.  Then put together a budget and you will know if you will be able to survive in that location.  Also, make sure you get updated information as to how much Social Security check you will get when you retire.  The number you quoted may only be an estimate, and I don't want you to be blindsided.  Generally, you will be able to survive with that kind of income from Social Security.  Avoid Manila, because it's very expensive there.  Hopefully this helps.
